metadata.title: An Novel Acetylcholinesterase Biosensor Based on Nano-Porous Pseudo Carbon Paste Electrode Modified with Gold Nanoparticles for Detection of Methyl Parathion

sections.text:
Delivered by Ingenta to: Florida State University, College of Medicine IP: 46.161.63.78 On: Mon, 19 Sep 2016 12:48:16
Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
Copyright © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved Printed in the United States of America
Article Journal of
Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Vol. 16, 9460–9467, 2016
www.aspbs.com/jnn
An Novel Acetylcholinesterase Biosensor Based on Nano-Porous Pseudo Carbon Paste Electrode Modified
with Gold Nanoparticles for Detection of Methyl Parathion
Yan Deng∗ †, Keke Liu†, Yuan Liu, Hongming Dong, and Song Li Economical Forest Cultivation and Utilization of 2011 Collaborative Innovation Center in Hunan Province, Hunan Key Laboratory of Green
Packaging and Application of Biological Nanotechnology, Hunan University of Technology, Zhuzhou 412007, China
A novel acetylcholinesterase (AChE) biosensor was developed based on layer-by-layer assembly of chitosan (CS), gold nanoparticles (GNPs), AChE and Nafion (NF) modified nano-porous pseudo carbon paste electrode (nano-PPCPE). The proposed biosensor exhibited a high affinity to the substrate of AChE and produced a detectable and fast response owing to its excellent electron transfer rate and satisfactory biocompatibility of GNPs/CS. Nano-PPCPE displayed good electrode chemical behavior, low detection limit and good stability. Nafion (NF) was used as a protective membrane of the AChE biosensor. The AChE biosensor showed favorable affinity to acetylthiocholine iodide (ATChI) with wide linear range (1 0×10−4–1 0×10−7 M) and an ultralow detection limit of 1 0×10−8 M. Under optimum conditions, the biosensor detected methyl parathion in the linear range from 1 0×10−8 to 1 0×10−14 g/mL with a detection limit of 5 0×10−15 g/mL. The proposed biosensor exhibited good sensitivity, stability, and reproducibility, thus providing a promising analytical tool for pesticide detection.
Keywords: Acetylcholinesterase, Gold Nanoparticles (GNPs), Nano-Porous Pseudo Carbon Paste Electrod (Nano-PPCPE), Methyl Parathion, Detection.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Organophosphates pesticides (OPs) have been widely used in agriculture due to its high effectiveness for insect eradication and low price.1–5 The toxicity of these pesticides arises from the formation of a stable complex through their reversible and irreversible binding to the active site of AChE that is essential for nerve impulse responses. The enzyme inhibition mechanism is that OPs can react with OH bond on the serine of AChE to inhibit the reaction with acetylcholine chloride (Ach). Therefore, the threats ultimately pose the need for the detection of OPs. In recent years, AChE biosensors on the basis of the principle of specific enzyme activity inhibition have been a hot research field in biosensor technology for rapid pesticide detection.6–22
Metal nanoparticles have been widely considered for improvement of the biosensors detection speed and stability. In general, electrons transfer from an enzyme molecule
∗Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. †These two authors contributed equally to this work
to an electrode via nanoparticles.23 Gold nanoparticles (GNPs)24–26 has been widely used in biosensors for improving the response, stability and sensitivity, owing to that GNPs with excellent catalysis, conductivity, and biocompatibility with enzymes.26–29 In recent years, the use of nanomaterials such as GNPs30 has caused their improved analytic performance in AChE biosensors. GNPs can enhance electron transfer reaction and improve analytical performance of the biosensors.31 Link et al. have used GNPs as signal-enhancing detection probes for determination of Ops with satisfactory results.32 GNPs modified glassy carbon electrodes for detection of methyl parathion show high selectivity, specificity, reproducibility and stability.33 Chitosan (CS) has not only the properties of low cost, biocompatibility, good film forming ability and nontoxicity, high mechanical strength, but also contains a good many of groups of –NH2 and –OH which are preferable to keep the high biological activity of the immobilized biomolecules. Hence, it possesses an ideal property for the preparation of modified biosensor.34–37 NF polymer is a cation-exchange membrane and is widely used for the
9460 J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 2016, Vol. 16, No. 9 1533-4880/2016/16/9460/008 doi:10.1166/jnn.2016.13059
Delivered by Ingenta to: Florida State University, College of Medicine IP: 46.161.63.78 On: Mon, 19 Sep 2016 12:48:16
Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
preparation of modified electrodes with hydrophilic, ideal conductivity, and insolubility in water. Recently, it was reported that SnO2-nanoparticles-carboxylic grapheme-NF modified electrode for detection of methyl parathion and carbofuran exhibited high sensitivity and acceptable stability.38 The NF–grapheme nanocomposite film modified electrode for determination of cadmium presented high sensitivity. Pt NPs-CGR-NF modified electrode for determination of carbofuran exhibited good sensitivity, acceptable stability, and reproducibility.39
PPCPE and nano-PPCPE have been fabricated and displayed good electrode chemical behavior and low detection limit. In particular, nano-PPCPE has an excellent prospect.40–45 Wang et al.46 47 fabricated nano-PPCPE using polystyrene microsphere as a template for detection of L-glutamate and Acetylcholine with high sensitivity, stability and good repeatability. Based on our previous investigation of PPCPE,41–45 to select carbonate microspheres as the template and pyrrole as a cross-linking reagent could fabricate nano-PPCPE displaying higher sensitivity and stability than that of the reported literatures (in printing).
In this work, the GNPs were fabricated based on the redox reaction between the NaBH4 and HAuCl4. 48 49 We investigated the behaviors of a novel AChE biosensor based on the AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE. CS containing groups of –OH and –NH2 was adsorbed onto nano-PPCPE with lots of pyrrole. By layer-by-layer assembly technique, GNPs adsorb simultaneously via electrostatic interactions and the formation of weak co plexs between N-ligands and O-ligands onto CS/nano-PPCPE. GNPs have properties of big specific surface area, high surface free energy and strong adsorptivity. The immobilized AChE on GNPs/nano-PPCPE exhibits greater affinity to its substrate and preeminent catalytic effect. NF was used as the protective membrane for the AChE biosensor. The stability and sensitivity of the modified electrode were ascribed to the synergistic effects of their large surface area, excellent electric conductivity and electrochemistry response of GNPs and nano-PPCPE. The AChE biosensor displayed favorable affinity and high enzyme activity to ATChI, and high electrocatalytic activity.

sections.heading: 2.1. Reagents and Apparatus
sections.text:
ATChI, AChE (Type C3389, 500 U/mg from electric eel), CS (85% deacetylation), NF (5% in lower aliphatic alcohols and water) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, USA). Methyl parathion was obtained from Aladdin. Nanometric calcium carbonate microspheres and graphite powder were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company (China). All other reagents were of analytical grade. Aqueous solutions were prepared with deionized (DI) water (18 M cm).
The electrochemical measurements were carried out on a PGSTAT302N (Metrohm). A conventional
three-electrode system was employed with a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode, a platinum wire electrode as the counter electrode, and the modified nano-PPCPEs as the working electrodes.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of GNPs
sections.text: GNPs were prepared by Du’s method36 through using NaBH4 as a reductant and stabilized with sodium citrate. Briefly, 1 mL of 0.03 M sodium citrate and 500 L of 1% HAuCl4 · 4H2O were added to 25 mL of DI water and stirred for 10 min. Then 500 L of freshly prepared 0.1 M NaBH4 was added gradually, and the solution color changed from colorless to wine red. After continuing to stir for 30 min, the solution was left undisturbed for 2 h and then stored in a brown bottle at 4 C. The density of the prepared GNPs is 0.01% (Wt/V).

sections.heading: 2.3. Fabrication of AChE Biosensor
sections.text: The modified electrodes were fabricated as follows: initially, the nano-PPCPE was coated with 3.0 L of 0.5% CS solution (Wt/V, 50 mM acetic acids) and air-dried at room temperature, then 4.0 L GNPs suspension was dropped onto the CS modified nano-PPCPE surface and air-dried at room temperature, and then the modified electrode was coated with 4.0 L of AChE enzyme solution (100 L of 0.1 M, pH = 7 4 PBS containing 0.2 M of AChE) and air-dried at room temperature, too. Finally, 3 L of 5% NF solution was dripped onto the above modified electrode, and dried in air at the room temperature to form NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE. As control, bare nano-PPCPE, NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/CPE, bare CPE, NF/AChE/CS/nano-PPCPE and NF/AChE/CS/CPE were fabricated using the similar procedure.

sections.heading: 2.4. Measurement Procedures
sections.text:
The NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE was first incubated in the PBS (pH= 7 4) comprising different concentrations of a standard methyl parathion for 15 min, and then transferred to the electrochemical cell of 10 mL PBS (pH = 7 4) containing 0.2 mM ATChI to study the electrochemical response by cyclic voltammetry (CV) between 0.1 and 1.0 V. The inhibition of the OPs was calculated as follows:
Inhibition % = iP control− iP exp iP exp ×100% (1)
Where iP control are the peak currents of thiocholine on the NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE and iP exp are the peak currents of thiocholine with OPs inhibition on the NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of GNPs
sections.text:
As shown in Figure 1, the prepared GNPs were displayed in a spherical morphology and homogeneous size, the average diameter of which was about 14 nm.

Figure 1. TEM image of GNPs.

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrochemical Behavior of the Electrode
sections.text:
Figure 2 shows that the Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) of the modified electrode, respectively. The results demonstrated that the EIS response of 0.05 mM K3[Fe(CN)6]+ 0 01 M KCl at the NF/AChE/AuNPs/CS/ nano-PPCPE (a) is much weaker than those at NF/ AChE/GNPs/CS/CPE (c), NF/AChE/CS/nano-PPCPE (e) and NF/AChE/CS/CPE (f), bare nano-PPCPE (b) and bare CPE (d) and the CV further confirms the above results. As shown in Figure 3, the current of 0.05 mM K3[Fe(CN)6]+ 0 01 M KCl at the AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE (curve a) is much stronger than those at the other five kinds of modified electrodes. Both the E S and CV results i dicate that the GNPs/SC/nano-PPCPE can be incorporated into the electrochemical system to improve electron transfer and catalysis which facilitate the electron transmission between the AChE electrochemical probe and the electrode. Besides, NF was used for protective membrane in order to prevent the loss of the enzyme molecules, provide a biocompatible microenvironment to maintain enzymatic
activity and improve the anti-interference ability of the biosensor.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrochemical Behavior of the Biosensors
sections.text: The CV of ATChI and enzymatic product thiocholine were investigated on NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE, NF/ AChE/CS/nano-PPCPE,NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/CPE and NF/ AChE/CS/CPE, as shown in Figure 4(A). No detectable oxidation peak can be observed at NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/ nano-PPCPE (a), NF/AChE/CS/nano-PPCPE (b), in PBS (0.1 M, pH= 7 4) blank solution. However, when 0.2 mM ATChI was added into the base solution, an obvious oxidation peak was observed on NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/ nano-PPCPE (Fig. 4(B(a))), NF/AChE/CS/nano-PPCPE (Fig. 4(B(b))), NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/CPE (Fig. 4(B(c))) and NF/AChE/CS/CPE (Fig. 4(B(d))), respectively. This oxidation peak was attributed to the oxidation of thiocholine (by the hydrolysis of ATChI), which is catalyzed by immobilized AChE. Obviously, the oxidation peak current at NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE was the highest, the one at NF/AChE/CS/nano-PPCPE was the second, and that at NF/AChE/CS/CPE was the lowest. The results demonstrated that the GNPs and nano-PPCPE both can greatly improve electron transfer which enhances peak current and sensitivity of the biosensor, but GNPs effect is stronger than that of nano-PPCPE. Meanwhile, GNPs/CS/nanoPPCPE could increase catalysis effect to decrease the potential in favor of avoiding interference from other electroactive species of biological matrix.

sections.heading: 3.4. Optimization of the Preparation of the Biosensor
sections.text:
The effect of the dosage of GNPs on the peak current of the NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE was investigated as shown in Figure 5. The dosage of GNPs ranged from 2.0 to 6.0 L, and the peak current increases with increasing
9462 J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 16, 9460–9467, 2016
Delivered by Ingenta to: Florida State University, College of Medicine IP: 46.161.63.78 On: Mon, 19 Sep 2016 12:48:16
Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
Figure 4. (A) The CV of PBS (0.1 M, pH = 7 4) blank solution on the NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE (a) and NF/AChE/CS/nanoPPCPE (b), NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/CPE (c) and NF/AChE/CS/CPE (d). (B) The CV of 0.2 mMATChI of PB (0.1 M, pH = 7 4) solution on the NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE (a) and NF/AChE/CS/nano-PPCPE (b), NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/CPE (c) and NF/AChE/CS/CPE (d). Scan rate: 0.1 v/s.
dosage. When the dosage exceeded 4.0 L, the peak current did not markedly increase and the base line became high, possibly because of increased resistance of the modified electrode. Therefore, the optimal dosage of GNPs was 4.0 L (0.01%) (Wt/V).
The peak current of the biosensor to ATChI was also affected by the amount of enzyme immobilized on the sensor surface as shown in Figure 6. Fewer AChE hardly ever catalyze and hydrolyze ATChI. The peak current increased with increasing AChE and reached a maximum of 4.0 L. Further increase in AChE led to a remarkable decrease in the peak current. Therefore, large excess AChE was likely to increase resistance and unstability of the biosensor. Hence, 4.0 L of 0.2 mM AChE was used in the work.
It is well known that the bioactivity of the immobilized AChE depends on the pH of the ATChI solution. The relationship between the pH of the ATChI solution and the peak current of AChE biosensor is shown in Figure 7. In
Figure 5. Effect of GNPs dosage on response current of the NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE in 0.2 mM ATChI. Scan rate: 0.10 V/s at room temperature.
the pH range from 6.8 to 8.0, with increasing pH, the peak current increased and reached a maximum at 7.4. Further increase in the pH leads to an obvious decrease in the peak current. Hence, pH 7.4 was used in the detection solution.

sections.heading: 3.5. Detection of ATChI
sections.text:
The affinity of immobilized AChE on the GNPs to ATChI was studied with CV measurements. Figure 8 shows the amperometric response at the NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nanoPPCPE polarized at about 630 mV in a stirred PB solution which was added an ATChI stock solution. With the increase in ATChI concentration, the amperometric response of the enzyme electrode increased. The range of the concentration of ATChI was from 1 × 10−4 to 1 0× 10−7 M with a detection limit of 1 0× 10−8 M. The apparent Michaelis–Mentenconstant (Kappm ) in the present studies was calculated to be 16.8 M
J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 16, 9460–9467, 2016 9463
Delivered by Ingenta to: Florida State University, College of Medicine IP: 46.161.63.78 On: Mon, 19 Sep 2016 12:48:16
Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
according to Lineweaver-Burk equation. This value is lower than that for AChE adsorbed on SnO2NPs–CGR–NF nanocomposite film (131 M)30 and for AChE adsorbed on PtNPs–CGR–NF nanocomposites modified electrode (148 M).29 Due to the excellent electron-transfer channels of GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE, the immobilized AChE shows greater affinity to its substrate ATChI.

sections.heading: 3.6. Effect of Incubation Time
sections.text:
It is recognized that pesticides have the same general structure and toxicological mode of action. The residual activity of the enzyme was influenced by the exposure time of the AChE to methyl parathion. The exposure time was controlled by incubation time of AChE with inhibitor. As shown in Figure 9, the inhibition of enzyme increased
(A)
(B)
9464 J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 16, 9460–9467, 2016
Delivered by Ingenta to: Florida State University, College of Medicine IP: 46.161.63.78 On: Mon, 19 Sep 2016 12:48:16
Copyright: American Scientific Publishers
along with the increase in incubation time. The curve trends to a stable value when the incubation time is longer than 12 min. The result demonstrates that the binding interaction with active target groups in enzyme reaches saturation. This change tendency of peak current reflects that the changes of enzymatic activity results in the alteration of the interaction with its substrate. However, the maximum value of inhibition of methyl parathion is not 100%, which may be attributed to the binding equilibrium between the pesticide and the binding sites in the enzyme.

sections.heading: 3.7. Detection of the Methyl Parathion
sections.text: As shown in Figure 10(A), after incubation of the NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE with different concentrations of methyl parathion, respectively, peak current of the biosensor was detected, respectively. The peak current decreased (curve b) in comparison with the unda aged AChE (curve a). The fact is that methyl parathion reduces the activity of the immobilized AChE. The decrease in peak current increased with the increase in concentration of methyl parathion (curve c). As demonstrated in Figure 10(B), the relationship between inhibition of methyl parathion and its concentration is linear from 1 0× 10−8 g/mL to 1 0× 10−14 g/mL with the detection limit as low as 5 0×10−15 g/mL. The linearization equation is I% = 10 21lgC−81 09 (r = 0 9996). The property of the biosensor compared with those reported in the literature is summarized in Table I.

sections.heading: 3.8. Interference Study
sections.text: The interfering signal was studied for the most common electroactive species. The signal for a 0.2 mM ATChI was compared with the signal obtained in the presence of the interfering species. The test results showed that no noticeable changes in peak current were detected in the presence of oxalic acid (0.5 mM), citric acid (0.5 mM), and glucose (0.5 mM), respectively, at the present operating potential in this system.

sections.heading: 3.9. Repeatability, Reproducibility and Stability Studies
sections.text:
The two relative standard deviation values of intraassay and inter-assay were found to be 2.7% and 4.3%,
respectively, indicating an acceptable repeatability and reproducibility. The AChE biosensor is stored at 4 C under dry condition when it was not in use. No obvious decrease in the response of ATChI was observed in the first 10-day storage. The enzyme electrode retained 95% of its initial amperometric response after a 30-day storage period, indicating the acceptable stability of biosensor.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSION
sections.text:
Nanotechnology has found more and more application in many scopes,52–69 especially in medical scope.70–78 Gold nanoparticles also are extensively investigated.79–92 In this work, a well-defined nanomaterial GNPs has been successfully prepared. This one-step synthesis is convenient and rapid. The GNPs with big specific surface area, high surface free energy and strong adsorptivity offered excellent biocompatible surface that was favorable for AChE adhesion, conductivity and biological activity maintenance between AChE and modified electrode. CS was used as a cross-linking reagent to immobilize the GNPs and AChE on nano-PPCPE. NF was used as the protective membrane of the AChE biosensor to improve stability and antiinterference ability. By layer-by-layer assembly technique, the NF/AChE/GNPs/CS/nano-PPCPE has been developed. The proposed biosensor exhibited good reproducibility and repeatability, acceptable stability, fast response, low detection limit and strong anti-interference ability and, therefore, has potential application in detection of methyl parathion pesticides and other OPs and CBs.
Acknowledgment: We acknowledge the financial supports of the National Natural Science Foundation of China (61471168, 61571187) and Economical Forest Cultivation and Utilization of 2011 Collaborative Innovation Center in Hunan Province [(2013) 448].

metadata.abstractText: A novel acetylcholinesterase (AChE) biosensor was developed based on layer-by-layer assembly of chitosan (CS), gold nanoparticles (GNPs), AChE and Nafion (NF) modified nano-porous pseudo carbon paste electrode (nano-PPCPE). The proposed biosensor exhibited a high affinity to the substrate of AChE and produced a detectable and fast response owing to its excellent electron transfer rate and satisfactory biocompatibility of GNPs/CS. Nano-PPCPE displayed good electrode chemical behavior, low detection limit and good stability. Nafion (NF) was used as a protective membrane of the AChE biosensor. The AChE biosensor showed favorable affinity to acetylthiocholine iodide (ATChI) with wide linear range (1 0×10−4–1 0×10−7 M) and an ultralow detection limit of 1 0×10−8 M. Under optimum conditions, the biosensor detected methyl parathion in the linear range from 1 0×10−8 to 1 0×10−14 g/mL with a detection limit of 5 0×10−15 g/mL. The proposed biosensor exhibited good sensitivity, stability, and reproducibility, thus providing a promising analytical tool for pesticide detection.
